Kuroneko.name: Kuroneko
Kuroneko.desc:
Kuroneko (black cat) is a Japanese horror film directed by Kaneto Shindo, distributed by the famous Japanese media distribution company.
The story takes place in feudal Japan during a civil war. The plot surrounds the vengeful spirits 'onryo', of a woman and her daugher-in-law.
Kuroneko.rating:
8.75/10 stars
For myself, this film captures a very important message through the use of horror and japanese folklore. As a culture that has always
praised its soliders and samurai, to see a film challanging the usual narrative is both interesting and inspiring to see the art of
cinema being used as social commentary. Furthermore, the director uses incredible techniques to capture this ghost story. The use
of lighting and framing techniques to create an atmosphere that is seeming stuck between reality and a ghost world is impressive,
especially with only black and white colour.

Sleepaway Camp.name: Sleepaway Camp
Sleepaway Camp.desc: An 80's slasher film directed by Robert Hiltzik that follows a girl to summercamp as a string of murders unravel, with a shocking ending.
Sleepaway Camp.rating:
8/10 stars
This film is really fun and entertaining, especially around Halloween.
This film captures the classic slasher film cliches while also doing something special.
This film really does capture the carelessness of summer for teenagers, yet also carries an eerie interpersonal twist. Definatly
a lighter, more fun horror film. There is a deeper message embedded in this film, however its arguably not the primary focus.

The Shining.name: The Shining
The Shining.desc: A Stanley Kubrick film that captures the spiraling madness and cabin fever of the Overlook Hotel caretaker.
The Shining.rating:
9/10 stars
This movie is plausibly one of the best horror/psycholigical trillers ever made and some of Kubricks best work.
The main reason I find this film so well done is Shelley Duval's acting. She basically acts by herself for most of the film. Acting alone without much help of
other actors or actresses is difficult. Not to mention, the emotional termoil Kubrick put her through while filming. For the directing
and stroy telling, Kubrick nails the slow build up of Jack going insane. You really feel like no one is safe
